awd_titl_txt: AGS-PRF: Atmospheric Lifecycle of Organic Carbon Through Multiple Generations of Aging
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a Postdoctoral Research Fellowship with the objective of characterizing the chemical properties of gas- and particle-phase carbon in the atmosphere. Laboratory experiments will be conducted in an environmental chamber to observe the formation of secondary organic aerosol and the aging of organic compounds over several days. The results will lead to a better understanding of the atmospheric carbon cycle essential for developing policies that mitigate the effects of organic carbon on air quality and climate.

The experiments will take place in a reaction chamber at MIT using a Total Gas-phase Organics (TGO) instrument, an Aerodyne Aerosol Mass Spectrometer (AMS), a Chemical Ionization Mass Spectrometer (CIMS), and other instrumentation to provide detailed compositional data about specific classes of compounds and their oxidation products. Up to three days of atmospheric aging will be simulated in the reaction chamber through the atmospheric oxidation of precursors using the photolytic formation of hydroxyl radical from a steady stream of nitrous acid. Several reduced parameter chemical representations will be developed to describe the chemical properties and chemical transformations of organic aerosol and to model its oxidation pathways in the atmosphere. The experiments will help to constrain the budget of total carbon in the atmosphere.

por.por_cntn:
A large amount of organic carbon is emitted to the atmosphere as volatile gases from natural and man-made sources. These gases undergo oxidation reactions in the atmosphere that transform them into oxidized organic gases, particle-phase mass, and smaller inorganic carbon-containing compounds (CO, CO2). Many of these products themselves undergo continuing oxidation, producing a complex mixture that is difficult to fully measure because it spans a very wide range of chemical properties; the extent to which all organic carbon in the atmosphere can be measured by currently available instrumentation is an open question. Without a complete description of organic carbon in the atmosphere, significant uncertainty exists about a number of important atmospheric processes, such as the formation of particulate matter, the removal of ozone and other oxidants from the atmosphere, and the chemical transformations and eventual removal of emissions from the atmosphere. The focus of this project is address this gap in understanding by studying an atmospherically-relevant complex mixture with a large suite of state-of-the-art instruments (primarily mass spectrometers) to completely describe the changing chemical properties of the mixture as it undergoes hours to days of simulated atmospheric processing. In the oxidation of α-pinene, a common biogenic emission, by both photo-oxidation and ozonolysis, ‘carbon closure’ of the product mixture was achieved, and parameterization of the carbon by its chemical properties demonstrated qualitatively and quantitatively that there was no carbon that could not be characterized. This project applied this complete characterization of the changing composition and properties of organic carbon to produce fundamental insights into the fate of atmospheric organic carbon, demonstrating that the global fate of emitted organic carbon is likely driven by processes impacting a few atmospheric constituents. By demonstrating that currently available advanced atmospheric instrumentation can fully describe atmospheric organic carbon, this project opens the door to unprecedented opportunities for exploring atmospheric processes and understanding the lifecycle and fate of emissions.

Many of the advanced instruments applied in this work are emerging as critical tools in the field of atmospheric chemistry but are only just beginning to see wide use. This project represents one of the first efforts to compare some of these tools or to use them to comprehensively quantify the entire mixture instead of just targeting individual analytes. The advances made as part of this project toward calibrating and cross-validating these instruments are critical for the future application of these tools. Furthermore, comparing the ranges of chemical properties of compounds detected by these instruments showed that there was little overlap in the analytes that they measured, with each instrument having its own unique strengths and limitations. By synthesizing these data, this project has demonstrated the utility of these tools and provided a framework by which future research can assess the “completeness” of their measurement suite. This project therefore yielded not only critical scientific insight addressing fundamental uncertainties in atmospheric research, but also produced an improved technical understanding of many of the instruments (and suites of instruments) used in the field.

The impacts of this project were further extended not only by involving a large number of early-career scientists in the research, but also by applying the expertise of the PI and mentor toward engaging undergraduate students in hands-on research. As part of Traveling Research Environmental Experiences (TREX), students designed and built low-cost air-quality sensors that they deployed downwind of Kilauea volcano in Hawaii. The students were taught to analyze and interpret the data using the software analysis approaches used for the primary research project, providing familiarity with research-grade tools and hands-on experiences that are applicable across all disciplines and fields.
